newsitem.title: USA: U.S. lawmaker seeks to boost natgas use in cars.
newsitem.headline: U.S. lawmaker seeks to boost natgas use in cars.

text.p: U.S. Rep. Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, introduced a bill Thursday to encourage more use of natural gas in cars and trucks.
The proposal gives tax breaks to owners of natural gas vehicles and to fleet owners who have natural gas refueling stations.
It also seeks to lower the tax on liquefied natural gas (LNG), which is taxed at a higher rate than compressed natural gas (CNG) that is used in natural gas cars.
A spokesman for Barton said at the right price, LNG would be used in vehicles because it is better for long hauls.

If the incentives became law, the bill would eliminate requirements under the Energy Policy Act of 1992 on private fleet owners to buy alternative fuel vehicles, and phase out similar requirements on states and fuel providers.
Barton said he would try to move the bill by itself or as an amendment to a related bill.
